  <item>
    <title>Cleaning is as bad for women as smoking 20 cigarettes a day</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91712/cleaning-is-as-bad-for-women-as-smoking-20-cigarettes-a-day</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122648" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/cleaner_0.jpg?itok=C2N8z7V5" alt="" />  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Harmful sprays can cause long-term lung damage and raise asthma risk by 40% - but men appear to be immune</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 2:57pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> Cleaning the house with chemicals is as damaging for women as smoking a packet of cigarettes every day, according to a new study, but men who clean their houses suffer no side effects.</p>
<p>Researchers at the University of Bergen studied more than 6,000 people who were either professional cleaners or had been regularly using cleaning sprays for 20 years.</p>
<p>The effect on female lungs was found to be equivalent to the damage done to women who smoked 20 cigarettes a day over the same period, <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/02/15/household-cleaning-products-bad-lung-function-smoking-study/" target="_blank">The Daily Telegraph</a> reports, and there was an additional 40% risk of developing asthma. Women, rather than men, were found to be at risk. Researchers failed to find any effect on the lungs of men who cleaned either professionally or at home, the <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-5397199/Cleaning-bad-womens-lungs-20-cigarettes-day.html#ixzz57HHdvlD2" target="_blank">Daily Mail</a> says.</p>
<p>Potential irritants include bleach and ammonia, according to the researchers, who said that chemicals used for cleaning were unnecessary for many household jobs. These could be performed equally well with microfibre cloths and water, they argued.</p>
<p>Experts in the UK say people should keep their homes well ventilated and use liquid cleaners instead of sprays, the <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/health-43085674" target="_blank">BBC</a> adds. </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/science-health">Science &amp; Health</a></div>    </div></div></description>

  <item>
    <title>Housing crisis could be ‘iceberg’ that sinks Tories</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91710/housing-crisis-could-be-iceberg-that-sinks-tories</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-83503" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2015/07/150729-housing.jpg?itok=VD0RMb68" alt="Housing" title="Housing" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Carl Court/Getty Images</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Housing</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Conservative MP Nick Boles urges PM to build more houses before next election or face backlash</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 1:28pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> The level of home ownership among young adults has “collapsed” over the past two decades, with the sharpest decline felt among middle income earners, the <a href="https://www.ifs.org.uk/publications/10505" target="_blank">Institute for Fiscal Studies</a> warns.</p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>Just one in four middle-income young adults own their own home, compared to two in three young adults 20 years ago. The reason is simple: prices have risen about seven times faster in real terms than the incomes of young adults.</p>
<p>As a result they have been “robbed” of the chance to buy homes, says <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/16/homeownership-among-young-adults-collapsed-institute-fiscal-studies" target="_blank">The Guardian</a>, while the <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5397697/Home-owner-crisis-just-one-four-afford-home.html" target="_blank">Daily Mail</a> talks of the “end of the home owning dream”. In the Mail’s front page article, Robert Colvile of the Centre for Policy Studies describes the reduction in home ownership as “one of the most dramatic, and damaging, shifts in our society and economy in recent decades”.</p>
<p>The knock-on effect of this decline could damage the Conservative party’s standing, according to <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/02/16/millennials-middle-incomes-half-likely-homeowners-1990s/" target="_blank">The Daily Telegraph</a>. “The fact that young, middle class professionals are half as likely to get on the housing ladder should panic the Tories,” says the paper.</p>
<p>Theresa May has been urged by members of her party to take “radical action” or face being pushed out of government in the following election, says <a href="http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/tories-fear-housing-crisis-middle-class-millennials-could-iceberg-that-sinks-party-1661821" target="_blank">Business Insider</a>.</p>
<p>“The doubly whammy of stagnant wages and spiralling house prices has had a devastating effect on the ability of people in their 20s and 30s to buy their own home,” says Tory MP Nick Boles.</p>
<p>“This is an iceberg warning for Theresa May and the Conservative Party: if we do not take bold steps to get more houses built it will sink us at the next election.” </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/property">Property</a></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/tags/housing-crisis">Housing crisis</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/housing">housing</a></div>      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/tags/theresa-may">Theresa May</a></div>    </div></div></description>

  <item>
    <title>Australian town to hold first ever ‘Mullet Fest’</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91709/australian-town-to-hold-first-ever-mullet-fest</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122629" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/mullet.jpg?itok=Er_GT6q5" alt="Peter Daicos mullet" title="Peter Daicos mullet" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> <span>Aussie rules football star Peter Daicos sporting a magnificent mullet in 1991</span></p>
<p><span> </span> </p>
</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Getty</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Peter Daicos mullet</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
‘The mullet scene is very strong here’, says contest organiser</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/reaction">Reaction</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 12:30pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> The mullet has largely fallen out of favour since its 1970s and 80s heyday, when the “business in front, party in the back” style was sported by everyone from Mel Gibson to Tina Turner.</p>
<p>However, the retro ’do has never gone out of style in parts of Australia, where it “became a symbol of working-class Aussie identity”, says the <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2016/09/28/mohawks-and-mullets-a-history-of-hair-in-australia_a_21482763/" target="_blank">Huffington Post</a>.</p>
<p><span>Now the small New South Wales town of Kurri Kurri aims to put itself on the map with the first ever festival dedicated to the barnet.</span></p>
<p><span>The winners will be crowned at the inaugural <a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/1544165978954487/" target="_blank">Mullet Fest</a> at the Chelmsford Hotel on 24 February, which will also feature music from New South Wales rock duo The Stunned Mullets</span></p>
<p><span>As well as overall winner, judges will award prizes to contestants in three style categories: “everyday”, “grubby” and “ranga” (Aussie slang for redhead).</span></p>
<p><span>One lucky lady will be crowned queen of the women’s mullet, while the mullet-wearers of tomorrow can compete in the “juniors” category.</span></p>
<p>“The mullet scene is very strong here,” the hotel’s owner, Laura Hawkins, told the <a href="https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/mullet-fest-in-kurri-kurri-honors-the-greatest-hairstyle-of-all-time/news-story/3af4239281209c7b8252694563a24d78" target="_blank">Australian Daily Telegraph</a>. “We’ve already had 50 entries.”</p>
<p><span>But Hawkins - who is also a trained hairdresser - admitted that the ladies’ category could use a few more entrants.</span></p>
<p><span>“I see plenty of lady mullets walking around town but I know they’re not signed up,” she said. “I think they’re a bit shyer than the proud male mullet.”</span></p>
<p><span>Hopefuls have until 9pm Sunday to enter their crowning glory in the contest.</span> </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/australia">Australia</a></div>    </div></div></description>

 <dc:creator>Rebecca Gillie</dc:creator>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>Google Chrome update brings ad-blocker by default</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91708/google-chrome-update-brings-ad-blocker-by-default</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122627" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/gettyimages-645846622-2_0.jpg?itok=syWdZO8G" alt="Google" title="Google" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> Google Chrome can be downloaded for desktop computers and smartphones </p>
</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">David Ramos/Getty Images</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Google</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Websites will be given 30 days to remove ‘disruptive ads’</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 12:02pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> <span>Google’s internet browser Chrome will now automatically block adverts in a bid to improve the way they’re displayed online. </span></p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>The tech giant revealed in a recent <a href="https://blog.google/topics/journalism-news/building-better-web-everyone/" target="_blank">blogpost</a> that the push for “compelling” and “useful” adverts had gone too far, with some web users forced to see ads for ten seconds before accessing the content on a page. </p>
<p>According to <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-43072266" target="_blank">BBC News</a>, the Coalition for Better Ads (CBA), a group which includes major companies such as Google and Facebook, will determine which adverts will be barred by the web browser’s ad-blocking programme. </p>
<p><span>Once the coalition has made a decision, the BBC says websites will be given 30 days to remove “disruptive ads” before the block comes into effect. </span></p>
<p>The programme will not be the “blanket advertising stopper” that many third-party ad blockers provide, <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2018/02/15/google-introduces-ad-blocker-chrome-will-work/" target="_blank">The Daily Telegraph</a> reports. </p>
<p>Instead, the newspaper says, the blocking programme targets “certain types of particularly disruptive adverts”, such as “flashing animated banner ads and auto-playing video adverts with sound”.</p>
<p>When visiting a web page with blocked adverts, <a href="https://qz.com/1207711/google-chromes-ad-blocker-heres-what-you-need-to-know/" target="_blank">Quartz</a> says users see a message in the address bar on their desktop computer or a small window at the bottom of their smartphone screen. </p>
<p><span>Chrome users can access Google’s ad-blocker on the latest version of the web browser, which is available on PCs and Apple Macs. It can also be downloaded on iPhones and Android devices.</span> </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/google">Google</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/tags/google-chrome">Google Chrome</a></div>    </div></div></description>

 <dc:creator>Cameron</dc:creator>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>Ten-metre sinkhole opens up in Rome street</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91707/ten-metre-sinkhole-opens-up-in-rome-street</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122621" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/rome_sinkhole.jpg?itok=sewwrD49" alt="" />  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Residents say they had complained for months of ‘shockwaves’ from drilling</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/reaction">Reaction</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 11:50am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> A gigantic sinkhole has opened up in the middle of a street in Rome, swallowing eight cars.</p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>The cave-in, estimated to be about ten metres (32.8ft) deep, occurred on the edge of a construction site in Balduina, a residential area on the north-western fringe of the capital.</p>
<p><span>Two squads of firefighters were dispatched to the scene, where dozens of residents had to be evacuated from nearby apartment blocks.</span></p>
<p><span><br />
<div id="file-122622" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-content-original">
<div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn2.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/2018/02/sinkhole_main.jpg" alt="Rome sinkhole" title="Rome sinkhole" />  </div>
</div>
<p></span></p>
<p>The cause of the landslide has yet to be determined. However, <a href="https://www.thelocal.it/20180215/massive-sinkhole-rome-cars-balduina" target="_blank">The Local</a> reports that work had recently been carried out in the area which collapsed.</p>
<p>“Both the legal representative of the company responsible for the construction site and the legal representative of the land's owners are under scrutiny,” says <a href="http://www.euronews.com/2018/02/15/investigation-as-huge-sinkhole-appears-in-rome" target="_blank">Euronews</a>.</p>
<p>Locals said that they had voiced concerns about the safety of the site several times in recent months.</p>
<p>“When they were drilling, everything would shake,” one resident told <a href="http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/cronache/voragine-roma-denunce-ignorate-mesi-tremava-tutto-1494870.html" target="_blank">Il Giornale</a>. “It was like shockwaves from an earthquake. My house was wobbling.”</p>
<p><span>Giancarlo de Caprariis, a lawyer who lives in one of the residential blocks on the verge on the construction site, said he had been in contact with the council about his safety concerns since last year after noticing signs of subsidence.</span></p>
<p><span>“There was no response,” he said. “It was a dangerous situation that no-one tried to solve.”</span></p>
<p><span>Another local said he had uploaded photos of the increasingly precarious site to Facebook. “If we could see it, how could the person in charge of the work not see it?” he said.</span> </p>
          </div>
      </div></description>
     <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 11:31:26 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Rebecca Gillie</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">91707 at http://www.theweek.co.uk</guid>
 <category domain="http://www.theweek.co.uk/europe">Europe</category>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>Video: Hector Bellerin slams ArsenalFanTV for feeding off failure</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/premier-league/91706/video-hector-bellerin-arsenalfantv-arsenal-premier-league</link>
    <description><p class="short-teaser">
Premier League transfer news, talking points and managerial mutterings</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 11:38am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <h3 dir="ltr">Premier League news and talking points</h3>
<h5>Bellerin hits out at ArsenalFanTV</h5>
<p><span>Hector Bellerin has criticised ArsenalFanTV for claiming to support it and then feeding off the club’s failures. </span></p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>Speaking at the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RoYzoe0FHMg&amp;t=5s" target="_blank">Oxford Union</a>, the Arsenal defender said that people were entitled to their opinions but he wasn’t going to listen to their advice.</p>
<p>Quoted by the <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/02/16/hector-bellerin-criticises-wrong-arsenal-fan-tv-feeding-failure/" target="_blank">Daily Telegraph</a>, the 22-year-old Spanish right-back said: “It’s so wrong for someone who claims to be a fan and their success is fed off a failure. How can that be a fan? It’s just people hustling, trying to make money their way, which everyone is entitled to do. For us players it doesn’t affect us. If they want to have fun with it then have fun. When you grow you realise what is important to you to take [on board].”</p>
<p><span>Bellerin added: “If a coach comes to me and says you’ve done something bad I’m going to take that advice. If someone from ArsenalFanTV says this guy needs to do this or that I’m not going to listen to him. They’re entitled to their opinion and the way they want to do it. If people find it funny then go watch it.”<br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">Hector Bellerin talking about Arsenal Fan TV.  <a href="https://t.co/W6g2J8msQy">pic.twitter.com/W6g2J8msQy</a></p>
<p>&mdash; Arsenal FC News (@ArsenalFC_fl) <a href="https://twitter.com/ArsenalFC_fl/status/964409666133377030?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 16, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p></span></p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Terry wants to return to Chelsea – as a coach</span></h5>
<p>Former Chelsea captain John Terry is keen to return to Stamford Bridge in a coaching capacity, the <a href="https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/chelsea-legend-john-terry-plotting-12034049" target="_blank">Daily Mirror</a> has reported. The 37-year-old is out of contract with Aston Villa in July and is eyeing a move back to a club where he spent more than 20 years as a player. The paper says that Terry wants to one day become Chelsea manager. A coaching role will help him achieve his dream.</p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Liverpool’s goalkeeper conundrum </span></h5>
<p>Sources have told <a href="http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3385214/liverpool-stepping-up-pursuit-of-romas-alisson-sources" target="_blank">ESPN</a> that Liverpool are “stepping up their pursuit” of Roma goalkeeper Alisson. The Reds have reportedly held talks with the Brazilian’s agent after a number of Europe’s top clubs were linked with the 25-year-old. ESPN says that signing a new goalkeeper is a top priority this summer for Jurgen Klopp, but the <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/02/15/liverpool-could-stick-loris-karius-instead-buying-70m-goalkeeper/" target="_blank">Daily Telegraph</a> suggests that the Liverpool boss is “ready to abandon plans” of signing Alisson and could stick with Loris Karius as his number one.</p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Hart ready to go abroad </span></h5>
<p>Another goalkeeper in the news today is Joe Hart. The Manchester City keeper is on loan at West Ham but has been dropped by the London club. Hart, who had a loan spell in Italy at Torino last season, wants first-team football. <a href="https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/5576584/joe-hart-manchester-city-abroad-west-ham/" target="_blank">The Sun</a> says that the England stopper would be happy to move to Europe again.<br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">%uD83C%uDD95 TRANSFER CENTRE %uD83C%uDD95 <br><br>The latest news and rumours as Real Madrid reportedly eye up Spurs defender Toby Alderweireld %uD83D%uDC49 <a href="https://t.co/VDhLv85eUR">https://t.co/VDhLv85eUR</a> <a href="https://t.co/81obdzNfsd">pic.twitter.com/81obdzNfsd</a></p>
<p>&mdash; Sky Sports PL (@SkySportsPL) <a href="https://twitter.com/SkySportsPL/status/964107136526704641?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 15, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><h3 dir="ltr"><span>Premier League transfer news and gossip</span></h3>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Spurs may consider offers for Toby Alderweireld </span></h5>
<p>Tottenham are confident that Toby Alderweireld will sign a new contract, but the <a href="https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/toby-alderweireld-could-leave-tottenham-in-summer-as-doubts-rise-over-his-value-to-spurs-a3767506.html" target="_blank">London Evening Standard</a> says that the club “may consider offers” for the defender this summer. <a href="http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3384693/tottenham-facing-dilemma-over-toby-alderweireld-future-source" target="_blank">ESPN</a> says that his £50,000-a-week contract expires in 2019 but talks have ended in a stalemate. The Belgian is reportedly a target for Real Madrid and Manchester United.  </p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Patrick Kluivert: La Liga may be a better option for Justin</span></h5>
<p>It’s understood that Ajax star Justin Kluivert has held advanced talks with Manchester United, but according to <a href="http://metro.co.uk/2018/02/15/patrick-kluivert-advises-son-justin-kluivert-amid-manchester-united-transfer-speculation-7315034/" target="_blank">Metro</a> the forward’s father Patrick has advised the 18-year-old to move to Spain’s La Liga. Patrick Kluivert, who played for Barcelona, said: “Justin is doing very well, and must keep going like this. He must keep his feet on the ground. I’ve told him that he is still 18 and should be relaxed and for sure stay another year or more at Ajax. I see my son playing more in the Spanish league than in the Premier League, but it will be his choice.”</p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Mauro Icardi: Inter Milan to Manchester United </span></h5>
<p>Mauro Icardi’s agent – his wife Wanda – is working with super-agent Mino Raiola to “push through” a transfer to Manchester United. The Inter Milan captain has been a target for Real Madrid, but <a href="http://www.espn.co.uk/football/blog/transfer-talk/79/post/3384585/transfer-rater-mauro-icardi-to-manchester-united-luke-shaw-to-chelsea" target="_blank">ESPN</a>, via <a href="http://www.corrieredellosport.it/news/calcio/serie-a/inter/2018/02/14-38436320/icardi_rinnovo_con_linter_ecco_quanto_chiede_wanda_nara" target="_blank">Corriere dello Sport</a>, claims that the Argentine striker could be on his way to Old Trafford.</p>
<h5 dir="ltr"><span>Malcolm: Bordeaux to Arsenal/Tottenham </span></h5>
<p><a href="http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11252106/malcom-confirms-bordeaux-exit-will-happen-in-summer" target="_blank">Sky Sports</a> reports that Bordeaux winger Malcolm has confirmed he won’t be allowed to leave the French club at the end of the season. The Brazilian, a target for both Arsenal and Tottenham, told <a href="https://blogdorafaelreis.blogosfera.uol.com.br/2018/02/15/na-mira-malcom-se-surpreende-com-tite-achei-que-o-grupo-estava-fechado/" target="_blank">UOL</a>: “Yes, there was a promise that I will be negotiating in June. I will choose the team, and Bordeaux will let me go.”</p>
<p>  </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/sport">Sport</a></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/arsenal">Arsenal</a></div>    </div></div></description>
     <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 11:27:25 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Mike</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">91706 at http://www.theweek.co.uk</guid>
 <category domain="http://www.theweek.co.uk/football">Football</category>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>UK should give £10,000 to everyone under 55, says RSA</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91705/uk-should-give-10000-to-everyone-under-55-says-rsa</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122620" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/pound_sterling_0.jpg?itok=QxkWJ1fj" alt="" />  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
London-based think-tank proposes new sovereign wealth fund to give Brits a basic state wage</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 12:27pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p class="story-body__introduction">Everyone in Britain under the age of 55 should be granted an extra £10,000 as a basic state wage, says a new <a href="https://www.thersa.org/globalassets/pdfs/reports/rsa_pathways-to-universal-basic-income-report.pdf?visitorgroupsByID=undefined" target="_blank">report</a> by the Royal Society for the encouragement of the Arts, Manufactures and Commerce (RSA).</p>
<p class="story-body__introduction">
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>Anthony Painter, director of the RSA’s Action and Research Centre, told the <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/business-43078920" target="_blank">BBC</a> that the money would help people cope with economic uncertainty and technological change: “A low-skilled worker might reduce their working hours to attain skills enabling career progression,” he said.</p>
<p class="story-body__introduction">The payments would come from a British sovereign wealth fund worth more than $1tn that has achieved a 4.1pc annual return, says <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/consumer-affairs/universal-basic-income-proposals-give-10000-everyone-55/" target="_blank">The Daily Telegraph</a>. To establish the fund, which is based on a scheme already introduced in Norway, the government should impose levies on big businesses or a “modest increase” on the taxes of the wealthiest in our society, says the RSA.</p>
<iframe width="100%" height="166" scrolling="no" frameborder="no" allow="autoplay" src="https://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=https%3A//api.soundcloud.com/tracks/342350391&amp;color=%23ae0e0e&amp;auto_play=false&amp;hide_related=false&amp;show_comments=true&amp;show_user=true&amp;show_reposts=false&amp;show_teaser=true"></iframe><p class="story-body__introduction"><span><span>Anyone receiving money from the Universal Basic Opportunity Fund would first have to set out how they planned to put the funds to good use. E</span></span>veryone would then get a £5,000 “opportunity dividend” for up to two years, taken at a time of their choosing over a decade. Dependent children could take their payment in the same year as one or both of their parents.</p>
<p class="story-body__introduction">The dividend would replace payments such as Child Benefit, Tax Credits and Jobseeker’s Allowance.</p>
<p class="story-body__introduction"><a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/rsa-research-universal-basic-income_uk_5a8589dee4b0774f31d2977e" target="_blank">HuffPost UK</a> calls it a “radical” new sovereign wealth fund invested to make a profit, comparing it to public funds in Norway, which work in a similar way. </p>
<p class="story-body__introduction">The UK fund would cost about £14.5bn per year over 13 years and benefit up to 70% of the population, <a href="https://www.businessinsider.sg/rsa-universal-basic-income-proposal-2018-2/" target="_blank">Business Insider</a> says. In comparison, the government’s pension protections cost more than £6bn a year and benefit only 20% of the population.</p>
<p>The RSA report is the third in a series aimed at highlighting economic insecurity as a major problem of our time. </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/economy">Economy</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/employment">Employment</a></div>      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/world-business">World business</a></div>    </div></div></description>
     <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 11:26:10 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Caroline</dc:creator>

 <category domain="http://www.theweek.co.uk/uk-news">UK News</category>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>Britain’s biggest security threats laid bare</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91704/britain-s-biggest-security-threats-laid-bare</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122631" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/drone_0.jpg?itok=swJuZIi0" alt="A Mikado electrically powered four-rotor silent flight capable reconnaissance drone" title="A Mikado electrically powered four-rotor silent flight capable reconnaissance drone" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> A Mikado electrically powered four-rotor silent flight capable reconnaissance drone </p>
</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Photo credit: PATRIK STOLLARZ/AFP/Getty</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">A Mikado electrically powered four-rotor silent flight capable reconnaissance drone</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
In Depth: terrorism, cyber-attacks and killer robots are looming problems</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/in-depth">In Depth</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 3:59pm</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> The Munich Security Conference opened today with a warning that international order is being weakened by tension between Washington and Pyongyang, strained Nato-Russia ties and the possible unravelling of landmark nonproliferation treaties.</p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>The world has moved much closer to the brink of a <span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e94-c485-463a-8acd23efef7a"><span>“significant conflict” over the past year</span></span>, conference chairman Wolfgang Ischinger said ahead of the meeting, which brings together the <span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e95-d20d-9637-49182fc68cb7"><span>world’s </span></span>defence experts and policymakers.</p>
<p>Theresa May is to address the conference on Saturday with a pledge to keep Britain’s European Arrest Warrant and Europol links, The <a href="https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/theresa-may-pledges-to-keep-eu-arrest-warrant-and-europol-links-lj2pkx6lg">Sunday Times</a> says. The Prime Minister is also expected to reassure EU leaders about the UK’s strategic direction post-Brexit.</p>
<p>May’s message will be that Britain wants a “close security partnership with Europe, whatever else happens in the Brexit talks,” says <a href="https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/london-playbook/politico-london-playbook-year-of-the-dog-mays-german-wings-florida-in-mourning/" target="_blank">Politico</a>’s Jack Blanchard. </p>
<p><span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e7c-6b0a-061e-cffc9296bbf6"><span>But what are Britain’s biggest security threats? The Week examines six of the challenges facing the UK.</span></span></p>
<h5>Brexit</h5>
<p>Former MI6 head Sir John Sawers says Britain must work out whether to align itself with Europe or the US post-Brexit, adding that “consciously uncoupling” from the EU will undoubtedly weaken Britain on the global stage.</p>
<p>“I think the country’s become less confident. And less outward-looking itself. And now of course we are saddled with the Brexit negotiation,” he said <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/brexit-leaving-uk-adrift-in-the-world-former-mi6-boss-warns_uk_5a855cece4b0774f31d2375f" target="_blank">in a podcast interview with Prospect magazine</a>.  </p>
<p>While countries outside the EU cannot take part in the <span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e9a-2bba-e018-9751fb51acf5"><span>region’s</span></span> foreign policy decision-making, the <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/5c9898e0-124a-11e8-940e-08320fc2a277" target="_blank">Financial Times</a> notes that the EU has said it wants a mechanism for “specific dialogue” and “consultation” with the UK – in part because Britain has a permanent seat on the UN Security Council.</p>
<p>The UK “will have to beef up its diplomacy in Europe after steep cuts to the Foreign Office,” adds the paper.</p>
<p>One European diplomat told the FT: “The fact that you are not in the room means you have to spend a lot longer working out where the EU is going next. I have seen the size of the American delegation and the Norwegian delegation.”</p>
<h5>Northern Ireland</h5>
<p>MI5 director General Andrew Parker, addressing an audience in London last year, said that the intelligence service was still countering threats from terrorism in Northern Ireland.</p>
<p>While the Provisional Irish Republican Army and the main loyalist groups have ceased their terrorist campaigns, some dissident republican groups continue to carry out terrorist attacks, seeking to destabilise Northern Ireland through the tactical use of violence, targeting members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland and causing disruption and economic damage, according to <a href="https://www.mi5.gov.uk/northern-ireland" target="_blank" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?hl=en-GB&amp;q=https://www.mi5.gov.uk/northern-ireland&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1518881998851000&amp;usg=AFQjCNEYW-eBeMsfMk4nG7EilXCQzjfU7A">MI5’s website</a>.</p>
<p>Northern Ireland’s top police officer warns that border posts and security installations erected in the case of a “hard Brexit” would be seen as “fair game” for attack by violent dissident republicans, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/07/n-ireland-police-chief-says-hard-brexit-border-posts-would-be-paramilitary-target" target="_blank" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?hl=en-GB&amp;q=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/07/n-ireland-police-chief-says-hard-brexit-border-posts-would-be-paramilitary-target&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1518881998851000&amp;usg=AFQjCNEI3KVBU-UnMInVs4WBTlr-xMEHbQ">The Guardian</a> reports.</p>
<p>George Hamilton, chief constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, says a “fortified frontier” would need to be policed around the clock and would put his officers’ lives in danger.</p>
<h5>International terrorism</h5>
<p>British Army chief General Sir Nicholas Carter says the threat from international terrorism has never been greater.</p>
<p>It has “diversified and is more dispersed, and we see the phenomenon that Daesh represents emerging in other parts of the world,” Carter said in a <a href="https://rusi.org/event/dynamic-security-threats-and-british-army" target="_blank">speech at the Royal United Services Institute</a>.</p>
<p>The terrorism threat will continue to grow, resulting in a “complicated tapestry of factors with extremist groups exploiting the chaos to seize territory and carve out an even larger foothold for themselves whence to launch attacks, including recruiting and inspiring our own citizens to acts of terror,” he added.</p>
<p>The long-term solution, Carter says, is to fix the causes of terrorism, which are “invariably a lack of education, a lack of opportunity and a growing feeling of exclusion and isolation often... coupled with a lack of opportunity and therefore a sense of impotence”.</p>
<h5>National debt</h5>
<p>Dan Coats, US director of national intelligence, told the Senate Intelligence Committee this week that America faces global and cyber threats from North Korea, Russia, Iran and China, in addition to an internal US security problem: the national debt.<span> </span></p>
<p><span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e8e-9d0c-d133-a13ebf0458a9"><span>“I would urge all of us to recognise the need to address this challenge and to take action as soon as possible before a fiscal crisis occurs that truly undermines our ability to ensure our national security,” said Coats, according to </span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com.au/dan-coats-biggest-threat-national-security-national-debt-2018-2"><span>Business Insider</span></a><span>.</span></span></p>
<p>Britain may want to take note. <a href="https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/governmentpublicsectorandtaxes/publicsectorfinance/bulletins/publicsectorfinances/july2017#how-big-is-public-sector-debt" target="_blank">UK debt</a> was nearly £1.8 trillion at the end of July 2017, 87.5% of gross domestic product.</p>
<h5>Cyber attacks<br />
<span></span></h5>
<p><span>The head of the UK’s National Cyber Security Centre says a major cyber-attack on the UK is a certainty.</span></p>
<p>Ciaran Martin told <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/22/cyber-attack-on-uk-matter-of-when-not-if-says-security-chief-ciaran-martin" target="_blank" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?hl=en-GB&amp;q=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/22/cyber-attack-on-uk-matter-of-when-not-if-says-security-chief-ciaran-martin&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1518883556292000&amp;usg=AFQjCNEa-Dxf5MmLhuHcSyQv28d6v3t5qw">The Guardian</a> he anticipated such an attack in the next two years: “I think it is a matter of when, not if, and we will be fortunate to come to the end of the decade without having to trigger a category one attack.”</p>
<p><span>Earlier this week the chancellor, Philip Hammond, told the </span><a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/14/businesses-must-do-protect-cyber-attacks-chancellor-warns/" target="_blank" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?hl=en-GB&amp;q=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/14/businesses-must-do-protect-cyber-attacks-chancellor-warns/&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1518883556292000&amp;usg=AFQjCNGb-K6TKsojFmKP7QE94dnCgk0z-w"><span>The Sunday Telegraph</span></a><span> that the centre had blocked 34,550 potential attacks on government departments and members of the public in the past six months – about 200 cases a day. </span><span id="m_7695637622489835974gmail-m_1008463532152656745gmail-docs-internal-guid-d94dbb41-9f50-ad80-cea0-bc33ab3d4362">The US and the UK also this week blamed Russia for a massive cyber attack known as NotPetya that wreaked havoc around the globe.</span></p>
<h5>Killer robots</h5>
<p>Killer robots may sound like a more existential threat but they’re one that’s no less real. <a href="https://www.politico.eu/article/attack-killer-robots-autonomous-weapons-drones/?utm_source=POLITICO.EU&amp;utm_campaign=6d0d7f3359-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2018_02_16&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_term=0_10959edeb5-6d0d7f3359-190118705" target="_blank">Politico’s</a> Janosch Delcker has reported on the imminent arrival of fully autonomous weapons, otherwise known as killer robots.</p>
<p>“Nothing illustrates the revolutionary nature of fully autonomous weapons better than the recent development of ‘swarming drones’ – small, unmanned aircraft operating in groups that could soon outperform existing military technology,” he writes.</p>
<p>“The size of swarms is limited now to hundreds of aircraft – but ultra-cheap, 3D-printed drones are being developed that, researchers believe, could be deployed as swarms of millions of tiny, insect-like craft within the next five to 10 years.” </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">

  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/security">security</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/tags/terrorism">Terrorism</a></div>      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/brexit-0">Brexit</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/tags/artificial-intelligence">Artificial intelligence</a></div>      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/tags/drones">Drones</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/tags/uk-debt">UK debt</a></div>    </div></div></description>

  <item>
    <title>Tesla Model 3 owner walks away from 60mph crash</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/electric-cars/91703/tesla-model-3-owner-walks-away-from-60mph-crash</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122617" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/presskit-model-3.jpg?itok=yRyzEDxG" alt="Tesla Model 3" title="Tesla Model 3" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> A Tesla Model 3 similar to the car involved in the accident </p>
</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Tesla</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Tesla Model 3</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Company chief Elon Musk outlines plans to improve vehicle safety after a driver shares his experience online </p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/reaction">Reaction</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 10:37am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> <span>A Tesla Model 3 owner and his passenger have survived a major collision relatively unscathed after their electric car collided with a stationary vehicle at 60mph. </span></p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>The driver shared his experience of the crash and posted images of the crumpled electric car in the Tesla Motors chat group on <a href="https://www.reddit.com/user/model_3_crash_dummy/comments/" target="_blank">Reddit</a> under the username Model_3_Crash_Dummy. </p>
<p><span>He told the chat forum: “Everyone from the paramedics to the tow truck driver said that people don’t usually walk away from this”.</span></p>
<p><span>“Had this been a regular ICE (internal combustion engine) vehicle I would be dead or in a lot worse condition,” he said. </span></p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en-gb"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Tesla Model 3 owner shares insight on vehicle safety after 60 mph crash - <a href="https://t.co/ayKls1j9jW">https://t.co/ayKls1j9jW</a> <a href="https://t.co/V8XT4M7sgp">pic.twitter.com/V8XT4M7sgp</a></p>
<p>&mdash; TESLARATI (@Teslarati) <a href="https://twitter.com/Teslarati/status/964227374798856192?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">15 February 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>The owner said he would provide more details after settling his insurance claim, but revealed that the passenger’s arm hit the car’s large touchscreen and “shattered it” during the crash. </p>
<p><span>This prevented him from opening the car’s glovebox, which contained details of his ownership and insurance. The passenger also sustained a “pretty big cut on her arm” from the cracked screen. </span></p>
<p><span>The crash prompted a response on Twitter from Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, who said the company would add a software feature that automatically opens the glovebox after a crash. </span></p>
<p><span><br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en-gb">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">Adding software feature to open glovebox automatically when car comes to a stop after a crash. Will look at bonding a thin plastic sheet to the front or back of screen.</p>
<p>&mdash; Elon Musk (@elonmusk) <a href="https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/964296857395478529?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">16 February 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p> </span></p>
<p><span>Musk also said that Tesla would consider adding a “thin plastic sheet to the front or back of the screen” to prevent it from shattering. </span></p>
<p>According to <a href="https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-3-crash-insight-60mph-collision/" target="_blank">Teslarati</a>, the driver has “already put in another reservation for the electric car”. </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/technology">Technology</a></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/tesla">Tesla</a></div>    </div></div></description>

 <dc:creator>Cameron</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">91703 at http://www.theweek.co.uk</guid>
 <category domain="http://www.theweek.co.uk/motoring">Motoring</category>

  </item>
  <item>
    <title>New York Fashion Week: Popcorn apocalypse </title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91702/new-york-fashion-week-popcorn-apocalypse</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122614" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/_mon0724.jpg?itok=dNhS5k3R" alt="" />  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
With many great designers leaving The Big Apple and some established names simply going through the motions, has the rot started to set in? </p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><span class="field field-name-field-author field-type-node-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even">Rebecca May Johnson</span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 10:14am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> In the wake of a fall of almost 1,600 points, the worst single-day slump in Dow Jones history, fashion commentators at New York Fashion Week had apocalyptic thoughts on their mind. The sense of downward trajectory was brought into sharp focus by the fact that the opening and closing shows were held on the floor of the American Stock Exchange Building.</p>
<p>For Lauren Sherman at <a href="https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/opinion/new-york-fashion-weeks-got-the-blues?utm_source=Subscribers&amp;utm_campaign=dcf24e8bea-new-york-s-thriving-gender-fluid-creative-scene-in&amp;utm_medium=email&amp;utm_term=0_d2191372b3-dcf24e8bea-417094573" target="_blank">The Business of Fashion</a>, "If it felt like 1987 that [first] night, with designer Tomas Maier's silk-pyjama-clad models sitting among modernist sculptures and feigning good conversation, that's because there are easy comparisons with then and now. In fact, Christian Lacroix, whose pouf defined the look of the go-go 1980s, staged his first show in New York a week after the Dow fell 22 per cent". The abandonment of New York by many of its most exciting designers in recent years – Thom Browne, Proenza Schouler, Joseph Altuzarra and Rodarte, and Victoria Beckham (due to return to Britain next season) – has left The Big Apple with a deficit in confidence, with few designers making the bullish creative statements the city desperately needs.</p>
<p><div class="referenced-gallery-node">  <div class="picture type-image file-gallery-adv-reference" data-delta="1">
  <span class="spacer" style="padding-top: 56.285714285714%"></span><a href="/91701/new-york-fashion-week-popcorn-apocalypse#1" data-gallery-id="91701" data-count="3"><p class="gallery-info"><span>Image 2 of</span> 3</p><img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/gallery_adv/public/2018/02/_mon0026.jpg?itok=294r5tHf" alt="" /></a><div class="field-group-format group_media_caption group-media-caption field-group-simplediv"><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-inline clearfix">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> Brandon Maxwell </p>
</div>    </div></div></div></div>
</div></p>
<p>The most highly rated show of the week came (again) from Belgian import Raf Simons at Calvin Klein – also in the Stock Exchange – though his designs were more batten-down-the hatches survivalist than Wolf of Wall Street. The dramatic set was filled with 50,000 gallons of popcorn that crunched underfoot, papered with black and white Warhol reproductions and hung with blood red mops by Simons' artist muse <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/23/fashion/the-artist-sterling-ruby-is-the-latest-calvin-klein-muse-raf-simons.html" target="_blank">Sterling Ruby</a>. "Then a model in a bright orange hazmat suit and waders appeared. Let's rephrase: Welcome to the pop-calypse," mused Vanessa Friedman at <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/14/fashion/calvin-klein-raf-simons-coach.html" target="_blank">The New York Times.</a> Simons continued in the vein of twisted Americana, established from the beginning of his tenure at the brand, and gave it the nuclear apocalypse treatment – Laura Ingalls Wilder dresses were cut out to reveal breasts and paired with heat-proof silver gloves. Two-tone cowboy shirts were teamed with end-of-days knitted balaclavas. There were thigh-high rubber boots that look like they'd suit a wade through radioactive goop. It was a show of ideas, a reflection on escalating global politics, a salvaging of America's past in an imagined neo-apocalyptic future.</p>
<p><div class="referenced-gallery-node">  <div class="picture type-image file-gallery-adv-reference" data-delta="2">
  <span class="spacer" style="padding-top: 56.285714285714%"></span><a href="/91701/new-york-fashion-week-popcorn-apocalypse#2" data-gallery-id="91701" data-count="3"><p class="gallery-info"><span>Image 3 of</span> 3</p><img src="http://cdn2.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/gallery_adv/public/2018/02/look-1.jpg?itok=fGTZahsN" alt="" /></a><div class="field-group-format group_media_caption group-media-caption field-group-simplediv"><div class="field field-name-field-file-description field-type-text-long field-label-inline clearfix">      <div class="field-label">Description&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><p> Monse </p>
</div>    </div></div></div></div>
</div></p>
<p><a href="https://www.ft.com/content/0d4910a6-0f4a-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb" target="_blank">Jo Ellison at the Financial Times</a>, posed the question "Is it time to wrestle with the fact that New York might be over? Certainly, it needs to evolve from its current incarnation. Or at least get a lot shorter…" Likewise, for <a href="https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/opinion/new-york-fashion-weeks-got-the-blues" target="_blank">Sherman</a> at Business of Fashion, "Save for Marc Jacobs – with his bewitching models decorated in blow-up rosettes and hiding under the broadest-shoulder blazers, Calvin Klein was the only true fashion moment of the week, the real reason to spend money on a plane ticket and a hotel room to be here in the flesh...As it stands now, the little jolts – The Row's ode to minimalism among the Noguchis, or Telfar's musical extravaganza – were sparse."</p>
<p>Respectable, competent luxury of the kind turned out by Victoria Beckham, Gabriela Hearst, and Rosetta Getty and a couple of legacy projects that keep the books ticking over, such as Oscar de la Renta and Carolina Herrera, are arguably not reasons to travel.</p>
<p>A few youthful brands with wildly varying aesthetics but a shared joy in their craft, elevated the sunken moods of fashion week attendees.  As Vogue reports, <a href="http://www.vogue.co.uk/shows/autumn-winter-2018-ready-to-wear/eckhaus-latta" target="_blank">Eckhaus Latta</a>, <a href="https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/fall-2018-ready-to-wear/monse" target="_blank">Monse</a>, <a href="https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/spring-2018-ready-to-wear/brandon-maxwell" target="_blank">Brandon Maxwell</a> were worth getting out of bed for. </p>
          </div>
      </div></description>
     <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 10:14:09 +0000</pubDate>
 <dc:creator>Show Media</dc:creator>
 <guid isPermaLink="false">91702 at http://www.theweek.co.uk</guid>

 <enclosure url="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/2018/02/_mon0724.jpg" length="645483" type="image/jpeg" />
  </item>
  <item>
    <title>Twitter reacts to Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux split</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91700/twitter-reacts-to-jennifer-aniston-and-justin-theroux-split</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122613" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/aniston_theroux.jpg?itok=7d8wGRca" alt="Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux" title="Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Kevin Winter/Getty Images</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
‘The gossip industry cannot resist an opportunity to invent’, couple say in pointed statement</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/reaction">Reaction</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 10:23am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> Jennifer Aniston and Justin Theroux have announced their separation, two and a half years after getting married.</p>
<p><span>The decision to part ways "was mutual and lovingly made at the end of last year,” the couple said in a statement released yesterday through Aniston’s publicist.</span></p>
<p><span>“Normally we would do this privately, but given that the gossip industry cannot resist an opportunity to speculate and invent, we wanted to convey the truth directly,” the statement said.</span></p>
<p>The former Friends star - the second-highest paid actress in the world last year, according to <a href="https://www.forbes.com/pictures/598b86c731358e60d775bca6/2-jennifer-aniston/#2a33b41f2211" target="_blank">Forbes</a> - married fellow actor Theroux in a closely guarded private ceremony at their Los Angeles home in August 2015, after a three-year engagement.</p>
<p>However, rumours of discord in the marriage dogged the couple. Speculation of a split reached fever pitch last week when Theroux remained in New York while Aniston celebrated her 49th birthday with a coterie of female friends in Malibu, California, <a href="http://people.com/movies/jennifer-aniston-and-justin-theroux-split-after-two-years-of-marriage/" target="_blank">People</a> reports.</p>
<p><span>Describing the split as “two best friends who have decided to part ways as a couple, but look forward to continuing our cherished friendship”, the statement continued: “whatever else is printed about us that is not directly from us, is someone else's fictional narrative”.</span></p>
<p><span>Aniston has hit out at the media in the past after enduring years of speculation over her love life and plans - or lack thereof - to have children.</span></p>
<p>In a 2016 op-ed, she hit out at tabloid culture, <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory/jennifer-aniston-justin-theroux-announce-separation-53126429" target="_blank">ABC</a> reports, saying she had “worked too hard in this life and this career to be whittled down to a sad, childless woman. </p>
<p><span>Nostalgic millennials noted that the separation, which comes five months after ex-husband Brad Pitt’s split from Angelina Jolie, means that both halves of the quintessential turn-of-the-noughties power couple are now back on the dating market:</span></p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr"><a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/JenniferAniston?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#JenniferAniston</a><br>When u realize both Jennifer Aniston &amp; Brad Pitt are now single <a href="https://t.co/Y9cxfIWQyH">pic.twitter.com/Y9cxfIWQyH</a></p>
<p>&mdash; Sonia Grace (@Sonia_GoodGirl) <a href="https://twitter.com/Sonia_GoodGirl/status/964287359360548865?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 15, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>
<span><span><br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">Somewhere, Jennifer Aniston is crafting her &quot;Hey, let&#39;s grab coffee and catch up&quot; text to Brad Pitt. <a href="https://t.co/pXLGo7O4Mp">https://t.co/pXLGo7O4Mp</a></p>
<p>&mdash; Madeline Hill (@mad_hill) <a href="https://twitter.com/mad_hill/status/964280091508342784?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 15, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p></span></span></p>
<p>However, others urged a reality check:</p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Y&#39;all really think Jennifer Aniston about to go sniffing around Brad Pitt when he got 10 kids and an alcohol addiction? Meanwhile she has a yoga body and a Smart Water deal w/ 0 kids in sight. She good.</p>
<p>&mdash; C.Rush (@cassterlyrock) <a href="https://twitter.com/cassterlyrock/status/964332406617468928?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 16, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>  </p>

  <item>
    <title>Did Corbyn meet a Communist spy during the Cold War?</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/91699/did-corbyn-meet-a-communist-spy-during-the-cold-war</link>
    <description><div class="primary-image">
      <div id="file-122616" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg file-default">
  
  
  <div class="content">    <img src="http://cdn1.theweek.co.uk/sites/theweek/files/styles/article_main_image/public/2018/02/jeremy_corbyn_0.jpg?itok=FxooSUHG" alt="Jeremy Corbyn" title="Jeremy Corbyn" /><div class="field field-name-field-file-credits field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Credits&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Photo by Rob Stothard/Getty Images</div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-file-alt-text field-type-text field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">Alt Text&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even">Jeremy Corbyn</div>    </div></div>  </div>
</div>  </div>
<p class="short-teaser">
Jan Dymic who’s described as a ‘smoothie’ is thought to have met the Labour leader several times</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 11:09am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p dir="ltr"><span>A Czech secret agent who allegedly met Jeremy Corbyn in the House of Commons during the Cold War was part of a spy ring expelled from Britain by Margaret Thatcher.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr"><span></p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>While Corbyn denies “knowingly” meeting the Communist agent in the 1980s, Czech secret police files “appear to show that Mr Corbyn was approached by Lieutenant Jan Dymic and hosted him in the House of Commons,” </span><a href="https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/comment/corbyn-and-communism-hr6m507p8" target="_blank"><span>The Times</span></a><span> says. </span></p>
<p dir="ltr"><span><a href="https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/5590660/maggie-thatcher-communist-spy-jeremy-corbyn/" target="_blank">The Sun</a> describes Dymic as a “bit of a smoothie with James Bond good looks”. The Czech agent posed as a diplomat when he allegedly met Corbyn on several occasions in 1986.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr"><span>“The Labour leader was apparently being used as a contact by Dymic in order to access information from MI5 and MI6,” the <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5397545/Communist-James-Bond-met-Corbyn-thrown-UK.html" target="_blank">Daily Mail</a> says, adding that the Czech spy was also trying to gather data about British industry and science, and information about <span id="docs-internal-guid-8d56c51e-9e30-f657-744d-be98050c3257"><span>America’s</span></span> nuclear activity.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr"><span>Dymic was one of several spies expelled by Thatcher’s government in 1989, three years after allegedly contacting Corbyn. During the 1980s, there was concern that Iron Curtain spies were targeting Labour MPs in order to uncover state secrets.</span></p>
<p dir="ltr"><span>The Labour leader’s spokesman says that Corbyn met a Czechoslovakian diplomat in the 80s but didnt offer or have any privileged information, according to </span><a href="http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jeremy-corbyn-czech-spy-response-labour-leader-cold-war-jan-dymic-mp-communist-eastern-bloc-a8212416.html" target="_blank"><span>The Independent</span></a><span>: “Like other MPs, Jeremy has met diplomats from many countries. In the 1980s he met a Czech diplomat, who did not go by the name of Jan Dymic, for a cup of tea in the House of Commons.”</span></p>
<p>The Times says that Corbyn’s denial that he “knowingly” met the Czech spy could have a simple explanation: “Given his activism at the time, he is unlikely to have regarded the formal diplomatic services of communist regimes in an adversarial light.”</p>
<p>Whatever the circumstances of the meeting, a Sun editorial says Corbyn has “questions to answer”, concluding “This man cannot be allowed the key to No. 10”. </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">

  <item>
    <title>Pictures: Dom Parsons wins Team GB’s first medal at PyeongChang 2018</title>
    <link>http://www.theweek.co.uk/winter-olympics/91698/dom-parsons-team-gb-bronze-medal-skeleton-pyeongchang-2018</link>
    <description><p class="short-teaser">
Briton takes the bronze in the men’s skeleton at the Winter Olympics</p>
<span class="field field-name-field-article-type field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">
      <span class="field-item even"><a href="/one-minute-read">One-Minute Read</a></span>
  </span><div class="field field-name-field-published-date field-type-datetime field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Friday, February 16, 2018 - 10:04am</span></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-body">
            <div class="field-item even">
        <p> Dom Parsons has secured Britain’s first medal of the 2018 Winter Olympics after claiming bronze in a dramatic finish to the men’s skeleton. </p>
<p><span></p>
<div class="field field-name-field-related-articles field-type-node-reference field-label-above">      <div class="field-label">See related&nbsp;</div>
  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/premier-league/91626/premier-league-transfer-news-harry-kane-real-madrid-wenger-alderweireld">Real Madrid target Harry Kane as part of £500m spending spree</a></div>    </div></div><p>After recording a combined time of three minutes 22.20 seconds, the 30-year-old finished just 0.11 seconds ahead of Latvia’s Martins Dukurs. South Korea’s Yun Sungbin won the gold medal ahead of Nikita Tregubov, an Olympic athlete from Russia.</span></p>
<p><span>Parsons is the first British man to win an Olympic skeleton medal since John Crammond in 1948. In his interview after the event, he said it was an “incredible” feeling to finish third at PyeongChang 2018 and a “bit of a rollercoaster.”</span></p>
<p><span>He added: “It hasn’t really sunk in yet. I thought I’d lost it after that fourth run, it felt like it had gone, I thought I’d binned it.<br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">He&#39;s already got his teddy, but Dom Parsons still needs to be awarded his bronze medal! %uD83E%uDD49 <br><br>The medal ceremonies start at 10:00 GMT so he should be awarded his medal at around 11:10. %uD83D%uDE4C <br><br>%uD83C%uDFA5 %uD83D%uDC49 <a href="https://t.co/nB1jY0BJic">https://t.co/nB1jY0BJic</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/bbcolympics?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#bbcolympics</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/pyeongchang2018?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#pyeongchang2018</a> <a href="https://t.co/XrdIdwk3gJ">pic.twitter.com/XrdIdwk3gJ</a></p>
<p>&mdash; BBC Sport (@BBCSport) <a href="https://twitter.com/BBCSport/status/964437680275599361?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 16, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p></span></p>
<p><span>“But Martins Dukurs has made some more mistakes and he’s the last person I’d expect that from – he’s been dominant for so many years. It’s just those little hundredths making a difference, it’s so close at the top. I’m just grateful that I got lucky.”</span></p>
<p><span>Winning a bronze was no easy feat. “Four years of work has gone into this, right from after Sochi [2014] when I started working with Kristan Bromley, this has been the goal from that point,” he said. “Sometimes it seemed like it wasn’t that close in coming and it’s just amazing that it’s all come together this time.”</span></p>
<p><span>Parsons’s bronze means it’s the fifth successive Winter Games where a British slider has secured a podium place.<br />
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">GB fans are out in force rooting for Dom Parsons and Jerry Rice.<a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/PyongChang2018?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#PyongChang2018</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/skeleton?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#skeleton</a> <a href="https://t.co/NDa1ypYI1N">pic.twitter.com/NDa1ypYI1N</a></p>
<p>&mdash; BBC Sport (@BBCSport) <a href="https://twitter.com/BBCSport/status/964323662198398977?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 16, 2018</a></p></blockquote>
<script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p> </span></p>
<p><span> </span> </p>
          </div>
      </div><div class="field field-name-field-category-secondary field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/sport">Sport</a></div>    </div></div><div class="field field-name-field-tags field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden">  
  <div class="field-items">      <div class="field-item even"><a href="/tags/team-gb">Team GB</a></div>      <div class="field-item odd"><a href="/pyeongchang-2018">PyeongChang 2018</a></div>    </div></div></description>
